video.title: Persona 5 Tactica & American Arcadia | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

I know high school kids tend to be
overscheduled these days, but this is just getting silly.

How many fucking battles for the soul of
humanity of the Phantom Thieves had to cram into their

last couple of years of high school,
before they turn 18 and become by the standards of

anime games over the hill, surprised
they even find the time to accidentally perv on
each other in the bath.

So Persona 5 Tatica represents Atlas&#39;
latest effort to hedge on finally committing to a

fucking Persona 6 for Christ&#39;s sake,
and I must say officially marks the point that I
got kinda sick of Persona 5 spinoffs.

Which is remarkable in itself, cause
the fucking dancing game couldn&#39;t manage that.

So once again, the Phantom Thieves
simultaneously the world&#39;s most extraneously large heist

crew and the world&#39;s smallest cosplay
convention get sucked into the metaverse and go through

a hideous torturous process that makes
their noses disappear and inflates their heads to
about twice normal size.
But besides that, it&#39;s the usual routine.

Shoot a bunch of monster dickheads in
order to make some dickheads in the real world less

cranially penile, and if I sound
dismissive it&#39;s cause I didn&#39;t get a sense that the plot

was dealing with any themes or situations
we haven&#39;t broadly encountered before in Persona
5 games.

Even with the twist that this time the
monster dickheads are projected from one specific

dude&#39;s cognition, it all comes down to the
same dickhead teacher and dickhead dad routines

that the individual Phantom Thieves
have already gone through one way or another.

Where it differs is that instead of fantasy
heists we&#39;re engaging in fantasy guerrilla warfare

to make a better fit for the new combat
system which is where the real effort is on display.

Or at least what effort it takes to copy
paste the combat from Mario and Rabbids 2 and stretch
the Phantom Thieves over it.

Tokenly, it adds the usual persona
mechanic of fusing and equipping personas to develop

a suite of elemental powers that exploit
different elemental weaknesses, but the sticking point

with that is the enemy
don&#39;t have elemental weaknesses.

Actually tell a lie, they all have the
same weakness to the element of being shot while
out of cover.
And how do you get them out of cover?
I&#39;m glad you asked, inquisitive voice in my head.

You do literally anything to
them that isn&#39;t a standard attack.

You melee them or burn them or freeze
them or shock them or hypnotize them or nuclear
them.

And call me an ignorant Emperor&#39;s
Newclothes non-seeing person but it kinda seems like

it doesn&#39;t matter a mildly chaved inner
thigh what specific powers you have equipped.

I don&#39;t mind that the combat&#39;s easy, that&#39;s
Persona&#39;s whole appeal, it&#39;s the fun, easy-going

branch of Shin Megami
Tensei where all the waifus hang out.

I mind that it&#39;s also boring, and that
so much of the attached flappery is ultimately
redundant.
So where else does Persona&#39;s appeal lie for me?
The dual world element?

That&#39;s absent, you just go from one
metaverse battle to the next, hanging around in the

green room in between to skip through
lengthy dialogue scenes and compete to see whose action
pose sticks their bum out the furthest.
The stylish menu design?

I guess we still have that,
although the menu organisation is a lot worse.

I don&#39;t understand why we have to go to
one menu to buy guns but then have to go to an

entirely different menu under an entirely
different subheading past nine flashy animated
transitions in order to sell our old guns.
Really good music.
Yeah alright, you can have a tick there.

Persona 5 Tactica is permitted to exist
as long as I can&#39;t be asked to buy the soundtrack
album.

I think it was wondering the third kingdom that
my boredom with the combat reached critical mass

and I decided it probably wouldn&#39;t make
a splash in the scandal press if I were to just

kick it in the head and watch
the rest of the cutscenes on YouTube.

After which I discovered I&#39;d
successfully predicted all the reveals and twists in the

plot, including that at the very end it
would turn out that the mastermind was a hitherto

unintroduced corrupted faux benevolent god
and we&#39;d defeat them with the power of friendship.
But not that I have the power of prophecy.

It was primarily my
proficiency in Persona pattern perception.

In summary, more like
Persona Slacktica, am I right?

Let&#39;s move on from being surprisingly
disappointed by a familiar IP to being surprisingly impressed
by an unfamiliar one.

American Arcadia is a fairly short
narrative indie game in which protagonist Trevor Hills,

nebbish middle manager and boring twat,
discovers that his entire life is a reality TV show

being watched by the people outside the
thinly disguised Disney World Resort in which he

dwells and is forced to go on the run
when he learns the powers that be are about to

disappear him for not
being interesting enough to watch.

Certainly hits close to home for
someone who makes a living on YouTube.

American Arcadia is
split between two protagonists
and two gameplay styles, 2D cinematic platforming

as Trevor and a first person puzzle
adventure thingy as the person on the outside trying
to help him.

Interesting, but some might say the game
doesn&#39;t make the most of its dual gameplay concept.

There&#39;s one section where you have to
guide Trevor on your monitor while simultaneously

bluffing through an awkward conversation
with management, and I wish there&#39;d been more of

that crossover stuff at all,
other times it just switches back and forth.

Some might also say the plot&#39;s hardly
original, occupying the precise midpoint between The

Truman Show, The
Matrix, Westworld and Pleasantville.

Some might also find it irritating that
it does the Little Nightmares thing where if

you do anything but the precise sequence
of actions intended by the narrative then you

get abruptly murdered like a horse
with a suboptimal number of functioning legs.

But on the other hand,
actually why did I like American Arcadia?

Well this is the thing, viewers, I
wasn&#39;t sure I was liking American Asphyxia.

The first person bits occasionally
descend into annoyingly obtuse sliding tile adjacent

puzzles and meanwhile the 2D gameplay
features a lot of pushing boxes around which is the

narrative puzzle platformer equivalent
of the inoffensive shade of pastel green used
to paint the walls of mental hospitals.

The very character focused story was
engaging enough but the dialogue&#39;s a touch shaky at
times.
I&#39;m getting a little bit sick of that thing Yuri

Lowenthal always does
when voicing nerdy characters.

deliver half his lines in an incredulous
high-pitched shriek like a 50s housewife noticing a mouse
in the kitchen.

But I&#39;ll tell you what it was that
flipped my thumb around to an upward direction.

American Arseburger probably has the
most satisfying ending of any game I&#39;ve played
in quite a while.

Obviously I won&#39;t spoil, but you know how
films with PG ratings are allowed to say &quot;fuck&quot;
precisely once?

If that&#39;s also the case with video games
and if there were some kind of annual prize for

best strategic use of your one permitted
fuck then American Aunty Nora would be my hot pick.

Goes to show just how important a good
ending can be in the grand scheme of things, as I

sit in my Yelp review for
my local Asian massage parlour.
